data.title: Undiscovered musicians will be able to write and perform in Paul McCartney's childhood home
data.meta_description: Paul McCartney is launching The Forthlin Sessions initiative, opening his childhood home to aspiring musicians.
data.text:
The initiative has been set up by Paul and his brother

Before they were famous, Paul McCartney and John Lennon spent many hours in Paul's childhood home playing music and the house has become known as the birthplace of The Beatles. Now up and coming musicians will get to use the space to work on their own music as part of a new initiative.

The music legend has opened his former home with the hope that it will inspire unsigned artists while providing them with a space to write and perform.

Named after the house's location at 20 Forthlin Road in Liverpool, the exciting new programme is called The Forthlin Sessions. Although it has been many years since Paul lived there, the site still holds special significance for The Beatles fans, and was a place of inspiration and creativity. Paul and John created many songs together in that house including 'When I'm 64' and 'I Saw Her Standing There'.

It has been owned by the National Trust since 1995 and became a listed building in 2012.

The initiative is also backed by Paul's brother Mike, and he will be involved in choosing artists to get involved in the project.

Speaking to Sky News, Mike opened up about bringing people into his childhood home: "This house to me, is a house of hope. And I hope it will be for the young people that come through the doors.

"I think it’s a brilliant idea, inviting young people to this house and giving them the opportunity of doing the same as us, coming from nothing and seeing where it takes them.”

He also reflected on hearing Paul and John practice together: “I would be in the other room learning photography, but whilst I’m doing all that I could hear guitar noises coming from this room.

"In there were what turned out to be two of the world’s greatest songwriters, McCartney and Lennon. They were rehearsing from a school book on the floor, that’s why this house is so unique.”
